It’s what originally pulled me into taking embroidery seriously as an art and led me into learning different techniques. </p>\n<p>Ever since my first infatuation with ecclesiastical embroidery – especially historical examples of it – I’ve been collecting old embroideries and old pattern folios.</p>\n<p>I think the pattern folios are pretty fascinating! They’re large envelopes or board covers (often tied together with ribbon) filled with massive fold-out sheets of patterns.</p>\n<p>The patterns themselves are ingeniously arranged, so that there’s no wasted space in the printing. Often, when patterns are meant to be repeated or substitutions can be made, letters and lines indicate the connections and suitable substitutions. Looking at these old pattern pages – and using them! – is kind of like putting together a puzzle.</p>\n<p>Today, I’ll show you some examples of typical pattern pages and how the designer gets as much use out of space as possible. We’ll also talk a little bit about symbolism, and I’ll share a pattern from an old portfolio that’s cleaned up and user-friendly.</p>\n<p></p><center><a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/ecclesiastical-embroidery-old-pattern-folios-a-free-design.html\" target=\"\"><img width=\"500\" height=\"698\" class=\"pinterest1\" src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/ecclesiastical-embroidery-pattern-folios-01.jpg\" alt=\"Ecclesiastical Embroidery Pattern Folios\"></a></center> <a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/ecclesiastical-embroidery-old-pattern-folios-a-free-design.html#more-44198\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">“Ecclesiastical Embroidery: Old Pattern Folios &amp; a Free Design”</span></a><div class=\"textwidget\">  <div class=\"div_wrap_sidebar\" style=\"text-align:right; background-image:none; margin-top:4px; margin-bottom: 8px;\">\n    <a href=\"http://www.crewelwork.com/blog/workshops-retreats/\" target=\"_blank\">\n      <img src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/lady-anne-needlework-retreats-01.jpg\" alt=\"Crewel Work Company\" width=\"310\">\n\t\t</a>\n  </div></div>\n\n<div itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Article\" style=\"display: none;\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/ecclesiastical-embroidery-old-pattern-folios-a-free-design.html\">\n<meta itemprop=\"name\" content=\"Ecclesiastical Embroidery: Old Pattern Folios &amp; a Free Design\">\n<meta itemprop=\"description\" content=\"If you’ve been hanging about a bit on Needle ‘n Thread for a while, you probably know that ecclesiastical embroidery is kind of a Thing of mine. Your experience, good or bad, will determine whether or not you ever use that thread again.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately, a bad experience can often turn us off a good thread.</p>\n<p>Over the years, I’ve written <a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/tag/threads\" target=\"_blank\">many articles about hand embroidery threads</a>, with heaps of tips that can improve your experience with them, especially with those that are troublesome in one way or another.</p>\n<p>Funny thing is, even the most basic hand embroidery threads have their annoying aspects. Hopefully, these tips will help you avoid the annoyances and just revel in the pleasure of threads!</p>\n<p></p><center><a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/hand-embroidery-tips-thread-taming-organizing.html\" target=\"\"><img width=\"500\" height=\"500\" class=\"pinterest1\" src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/embroidery-thread-taming-organizing-01.jpg\" alt=\"Hand Embroidery Tips - Thread Taming &amp; Organizing\"></a></center> <a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/hand-embroidery-tips-thread-taming-organizing.html#more-44645\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">“Hand Embroidery Tips: Thread Taming &amp; Organizing”</span></a><div class=\"textwidget\">  <div class=\"div_wrap_sidebar\" style=\"text-align:right; background-image:none; margin-top:4px; margin-bottom: 8px;\">\n    <a href=\"http://thistle-threads.myshopify.com/products/stumpwork-lion\" target=\"_blank\">\n      <img src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Thistle-Threads-Oct-2016.jpg\" alt=\"Thistle Threads\" width=\"310\">\n\t\t</a>\n  </div></div>\n\n<div itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Article\" style=\"display: none;\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/hand-embroidery-tips-thread-taming-organizing.html\">\n<meta itemprop=\"name\" content=\"Hand Embroidery Tips: Thread Taming &amp; Organizing\">\n<meta itemprop=\"description\" content=\"Whether you’re new to embroidery or you’ve been stitching a while, you either have, or will – inevitably – run into certain frustrations with thread! Or more important even than the threads you plan to use. </p>\n<p>But to help clarify my assertion, think about it: without something to embroidery <i>on</i>, there’s really no point to embroidery at all!</p>\n<p>So let’s have a little chat about fabric, and more specifically, about fabric that is used widely in the needlework world – specifically, linen, and more specifically, even-weave and plain-weave linen and the differences between them.</p>\n<p></p><center><a target=\"\" href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/fabric-for-embroidery-plain-weave-vs-even-weave.html\"><img width=\"500\" height=\"500\" src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/fabric-for-embroidery-01.jpg\" alt=\"fabric for embroidery: plain weave vs even weave\"></a></center> <a href=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/fabric-for-embroidery-plain-weave-vs-even-weave.html#more-44617\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">“Fabric for Embroidery: Plain Weave vs. Even Weave”</span></a><div class=\"textwidget\"><div class=\"div_wrap_sidebar\" style=\"text-align:right; background-image:none; margin-top:4px; margin-bottom: 8px;\">\n    <a href=\"https://www.crewelwork.com\" target=\"_blank\">\n      <img src=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Crewel-Work-Company-2.jpg\" alt=\"Crewel Work Company\" width=\"310\">\n\t\t</a>\n  </div></div>\n\n<div itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Article\" style=\"display: none;\">\n<meta itemprop=\"url\" content=\"https://www.needlenthread.com/2017/04/fabric-for-embroidery-plain-weave-vs-even-weave.html\">\n<meta itemprop=\"name\" content=\"Fabric for Embroidery: Plain Weave vs. Even Weave\">\n<meta itemprop=\"description\" content=\"Good morning and a Happy Friday all around! Today, I’ll show you those, including the one I settled on that worked well for transferring the letters in preparation for some simple embroidery.</p>\n<p>I still want to fiddle about with other transfer ideas.
